awd_titl_txt: EAGER:   Evaluating the efficacy of the DSV-2 Alvin in scientific operations via a scientific verification cruise (SVC)

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: PRESIDENT AND FELLOWS OF HARVARD COLLEGE

por.por_cntn:
Background: The human occupied submersible Alvin is arguably the most accomplished deep sea research vehicle in the world.  It has played a role in the discovery of hydrothermal vents (underwater hot springs that harbor tremendous communities of unique animals and microbes), the discovery of numerous sunken vessels including the RMS Titanic, and was one of the first deep sea vehicles to respond to the Deepwater Horizon accident.  

Around the turn of the century, scientists began seriously discussing an Alvin upgrade, in which they proposed to update the vehicle with state-of-the-art sensors and cameras, as well as advanced power and propulsion systems.  Subsequently, the National Science Foundation in partnership with other federal agencies approved a program to upgrade the HOV Alvin with the aforementioned technologies.  In addition, the vehicle was updated with new flotation foam and pressure housings that would allow the submersible to dive to 6500 meters (pending additional upgrades).

Over the past five years, HOV Alvin has undergone a suite of enhancements including a new pressure hull with improved visibility and ergonomics, new digital imaging and data acquisition systems, a novel basket that accommodates greater payloads, and numerous improvements to the vehicle’s command and control systems. The new pressure sphere has been certified to 6500m. Future upgrades to the submarine’s batteries and other major subsystems will ultimately make this HOV capable of operations at 6500 m.

Completion of Navy sea trials occurred in late 2013, and resulted in Alvin being re-certified for operations.  However, there are key aspects of vehicle operation and performance that are critical to science but not necessarily included in the certification process as defined by the US Navy’s protocols. 

Consequently, we requested support for a science verification cruise (SVC) that will be conducted to assess the research capabilities of the vehicle.  The specific objectives of the cruise will include:  1) involvement of experienced users to ensure operational components and scientific sensors on the vehicle are working properly, 2) pursuit of various science projects and opportunistic exploration, and 3) education of select early career scientists who intend to write proposals for deep submergence field science using HOV Alvin in the coming months. 

Project outcomes: The Science Verification cruise took place on March 13-25, 2105.  During this time, the evaluators produced a comprehensive report that describes the vehicle’s scientific capabilities and limitations, and specifically addressed and commented upon the specific capabilities.  These documents are available to the broader community via the UNOLS website (see https://www.unols.org/node/20031), and can be used to provide guidance to future users, and to address and resolve issues prior to their expeditions.

Briefly, the evaluators found that the upgraded Alvin was, on the whole, a superior platform for scientific activities.  The personnel sphere is markedly larger and more comfortable. Seating in the upgraded vehicle is much more accommodating.  The sub has been equipped with thick foam mats that provide a variety of comfortable seating positions for a people of different shapes and sizes.  The forward viewports are spectacular. Most observers were delighted with the overlap between the pilot’s’ and observers’ viewports.  Observers also commented on the spectacular field of view that one has when they sit up close to the viewport.
